title: family woes the queen let go of reigns
story: Unencumbered by a relentless schedule of pressing the flesh around the country, she’s having the first extended break of her admirably dutul le.A rare sighting of her on horseback shows her deep in thought, perhaps reflecting, as we all do in moments of quiet contemplation, on the well- being of her loved ones. In her case, it’s not pretty.Where to start  How about son number two who, thanks to his friendship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein is now embroiled in an ugly, cross-Atlantic ding dong with an American legal system that kowtows to no one.Clearly, Andrew hoped his royal status might ensure discretion. But the US Department of Justice has other ideas and has now publicly accused him of lying when he says he has offered to co-operate with their inquiries into Epstein’s questionable activities.It’s uncertain whether The Queen and Prince Philip have Netflix in their lockdown lair at Windsor Castle, butthey have watched the documentary Jeffrey Epstein: Filthy Rich — in which their reportedly favourite son is mentioned many times — they will have spat out their popcorn.Aside from the well- documented claim by Virginia Roberts that she was trafficked to London at the age of  to have sex with Prince Andrew , one of the most damning accusations is the alleged sighting of him at Epstein’s private island where airport staff now say that the billionaire, who allegedly killed himself last year, frequently arrived with “underage girls”.Ordinary people staying schtum at the time for fear of losing their jobs is one thing but the silence of the many powerful men who enjoyed Epstein’s hospitality is quite another.Prince Andrew is undoubtedly one of them and, at the very least, he owes it to Epstein’s survivors to sit down with the US Department of Justice and reveal what he does, or doesn’t, know.And asthat’s not enough to give his mother sleepless nights, he and his ex-we Sarah Ferguson are also being sued for a £.million unpaid debt on a Swiss ski chalet.Meanwhile, son number oneis happy enough in his second marriage, but reportedly harbouring a deep sadness that one of his sons has chosen to leg it to the US, along with the baby grandson he can no longer hug.On top of that, he faces forking out millions to help Harry and Meghan pay for personal protection because not only have they chosen to settle down in paparazzi central, but in a country where the gun culture means any nutter can wander into a store and arm up as easily as buying a microwave.Son number threehas just announced that his children won’t use royal titles and will work for a living.But one wonders whether, given the pressure to streamline the monarchy, they jumped before they were pushed.Daughter Anne is a reliable stalwart, but grandson Peter recently announced his marriage to we Autumn is over, and as for grandsons William and Harry, it’s fair to say that the reported fall-out of those two young brothers who walked so stoically behind their mother’s coffin must be causing The Queen great sadness.So, with all that going on with her nearest and dearest, how will she feel when lockdown finally lts and she’s expected to put on a brave face to the world again Will she think, “I’ve had enough” and, as was rumoured prior to the pandemic, abdicate on her th birthday next year Doubtful, given that she pledged she would be of service “my whole le” and that, traditionally, British monarchs occupy the throne until death.But, given her family ructions, who could blame hershe did decide to call it a day If he had bodyguards with him on his ious visits to Epstein, then perhaps they could enlighten the US authorities on Andrew’s movements at the time Andhe didn’t, then why the hell does he need them now Asthe new, -day quarantine rule wasn’t daft enough, it’s emerged that police have been told to take “no immediate action”a passenger gives a  address on arrival in the UK.Right. So the only travellers affected by this ludicrous policy will be the law-abiding and public figures who risk being spotted on holiday then named and shamedthey don’t self-isolate upon .Everyone  can just give their details as Mickey Mouse of Taking The Mickey Street, and go about their le with impunity.Meanwhile, the airline industry is teetering on the verge of bankruptcy because it sends out the message that Britain is closed.Well. Done. Everyone.Prince Albert of Monaco has a problem – his subjects are getting too old.According to the BBC documentary Inside Monaco, it’s the most elderly country on Earth.So the principality has launched an “influencer” award aimed at attracting a younger “YouTube” generation who,the footage of their garish supercars is anything to go by, have money but zero taste.The awards are the brainchild of the prince’s friend . . .  . . .  Princess Camilla of Bourbon Two Sicilies, Duchess of Castro If Little Britain ever doesto our screens, she’s a shoo-in.Dancing On Ice is reportedly considering filming the show with two-metre social-distancing measures in place.If the rumours of their big fallout are true, last series contestant Caprice and her dance partner Hamish Gaman would have had no trouble with implementing it.Pixar’s animated movie Coco has been voted the most tear-jerking film of all time, with Marley  Me in second place and Schindler’s List in third.It was the result of a Twitter survey by US film critic Kevin Lee, who asked followers to tell him “the hardest you’ve ever cried in a movie TV show”.I haven’t seen Coco, but my weepiest, cinematic experience didn’t make the top ten.It’s Mask – starring Cher and Eric Stolz – a film that rendered me so inconsolable that the man in front of me askedI could “shut the hell up”.And Goodbye Mr Chips wasn’t far behind either – but at least I was home on the sofa for that one.Other than Leonardo DiCaprio browsing for a new girlfriend, who actually shops at underwear store Victoria’s Secret any more Not many Brits, it seems – its  UK stores have just gone in to administration.Back in the day, VS underwear was tasteful and good quality, but somewhere along the way it lost sight of its core customer.The owners clearly forgot that, while men lusted after the scantily-clad “Angels” such as Alessandra Ambrosio at its catwalk shows , it’s primarily women who buy lingerie.And the majority want “tastefully boudoir” not “garishly bordello”.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: banning china huawei 5g world less safe
story: Marcus Willett, former deputy head of the governments listening post GCHQ, said freezing China out would split the internet in two and make attacks between each side more likely.China relies on western tech – its army uses Microsoft Windows and the telecoms firm Huawei uses hi-tech US chips to make its G kit, he said.The tactic of freezing China out, and encouraging allies to do the same, pushes us down a strategic path that, in the end, makes the globe less secure, he warned.It is far more sensible to think of a future with them entangled and entwined with US and Chinese technology.A global US crackdown on companies selling chips to Huawei will bolster Beijing’s homegrown tech firms and lead to a “splinternet,” he said.You end up with two separate ecosystems in cyberspace. The free world model or the Chinese surveillance model which can look very attractive to a lot of the developing world.”The former spy, who served more than  years, insisted Britain could manage the risk posed by Huawei’s current G kit. He dismissed US threats to stop intelligence sharingBritain used G as “spurious”.Boris Johnson has faced a backlash from Tory MPs calling for Huawei to be banned from Britain’s G network on security grounds.“The idea Beijing will change its ways and stop trying to export its dictatorial systemwe adopt Huawei tech is laughable,” said Neil O’Brien, a Conservative MP and founder of the China Research Group.Natos chief Jens Stoltenburg warned China was changing the global balance of power yesterday and he urged like minded countries to stand up to its bullying and coercion.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: school closures poor kids years behind
story: There has been a massive dference in levels of online learning offered to poorer children compared to wealthier pupils, the Institute for Fiscal Studies has said.The shocking findings from the IFS come after MPs warned there could be a lost generation of school children and have been calling for a catch up premium for left-behind kids.According to the IFS, children from better-off families have had a richer resource base to continue their learning from home.Britains richest primary school children have been spending just over  hours a day in online classes, compared with just over  hour a day for poorer pupils.The IFS report said: Private schools are almost twice as likely to be providing online teaching as the state schools attended by children from the fth most deprived families.Better-off pupils also have better home facilities and are much more likely to have private tutoring.This could put back years of slow progress on social mobility.For secondary state school pupils, the wealthier kids have been spending almost three hours a day on online working, compared to just over  hours for less-well of students.The only area of educational activities poor students excelled over their wealthier counterparts was in home learning packs - roughly  per cent of Britains poorest kids had access to packages of material, compared to just over  per cent.But wealthy kids were iniably getting better access to crucial online classes - almost  per cent, compared to  per cent.For those in private school the number was even higher - almost  per cent of privately educated children were getting online classes.The report said: These gaps mean that children from better-off families are not only doing a higher quantity of home learning, they also have access to potentially higher-quality support from schools.The activities that children from better-off families are doing may also require less parental support because they involve a more active engagement from teachers and tutors.The report warned parents of poorer kids were more likely to be overloaded with helping their children as well as trying to work.The report added: It is almost certain that these factors will coalesce to widen an already prominent attainment gap between children from poorer and better-off background in England.According to the IFS this dference in schooling could entrench inequalities and scar kids careers long after finishing school.Children in poorer families have lost more from school closures, and those who would have entered work this year face the potential for long-term scarring from the collapsing labour market.In contrast, iniduals with higher levels of education and higher earnings are more likely to be able to carry out their work activities from their home, to have space at home to educate their children.And to have savings to cover any unforeseen expenditures.Schools have only just opened up this month after closing for everyone but children of key workers in March.Kids in reception, year one and year six are all able toto classes, but the Government recently ditched its plans to get all primary school kids back before the holidays.Childrens Commissioner Anne Longfield accused the Government earlier this week of prioritising the reopening of pubs of kids education.She told BBC Radio : Lets look at some of the things the Government has prioritised over recent months at vast scale and speed - the measures to save jobs, the ,-bed hospitals, propping up the economy.All of those things have happened in a way that is unimaginable.Its that level of will and determination thats needed to overcomer the practicality thats needed nowChildrens education does matter as much as the economy and we need to invest in it because without it title: lockdown workers skiving two hours without boss noticing
story: A quarter of employees say working from home means they can get away with doing less without getting caught.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMost Brits work an average of . hours a week - but many are now doing much less.A poll revealed people working from home due to coronavirus have been doing two hours and  minutes less each day - or  hours and  minutes a week.Three in  blame the pandemic for making them less productive.The survey found lockdown has meant a  per cent drop in productivity - equivalent to almost two days less work each week.And it is the stress of working from home that has seen people try to cut down their hours.Many admitted they can now get away with working less each day - and their managers dont notice. The survey, by Mind Gym and Censuswide, also revealed that more than a third of workers have seen a decline in their mental health since being locked down.Feeling isolated and anxious, as well as being away from colleagues and authority, is making people burn out. With almost half the UK workforce working from home, the company has warned this could have “catastrophic” consequences.Mind Gym chief executive Octavius Black said: “Given the anxiety from lockdown and the ineffectiveness of managers in this new environment, masses of UK workers are likely either to opt-out or burnout.“The impact on the UK’s productivity would be catastrophic.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle to focus on supporting black lives matter as she considers herself a role model royal expert claims
story: Vanity Fairs Royal Correspondent Katie Nicholl claims Meghan and Prince Harry now plan to focus their attention on the rapidly-expanding campaign group. She said during lockdown the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have been kept very busy focusing on the impact of COVID-.However, Katie told Entertainment Tonight:  The Black Lives Matter movement matters to Meghan and it matters to Harry. And I understand that this is going to be an area where were going to see the couple doing a lot more work and taking a lot more interest.The author and broadcaster said the couples ying backgrounds give them dferent perspectives on the movement which she added really resonates with them both.And she claims Meghan is particularly passionate about the issue and sees herself as a role model able to speak out on the issue of racial equality.She said: She believes that there is an expectation on her to address whats going on and tosupport. And that is what theyre doing.Last week, Meghan spoke out over George Floyd’s death saying his le mattered in a heartfelt video message against racism.The unarmed black man died in police custody in Minneapolis, Minnesota, last week after a cop was filmed kneeling on his neck during his arrest.Floyd was slowly murdered by Derek Chauvin in broad daylight as he cried and screamed into the pavement that he couldnt breathe because Chauvin was kneeling on his neck.The tragedy sparked widespread outrage and protests which have spread across the US, the UK and the rest of the world.Meghan compared Floyds death to those of other African Americans who have died in police custody.She said: “George Floyd’s le mattered and Breonna Taylor’s le mattered and Philando Castile’s le mattered and Tamir Rice’s le mattered… and so did so many other people whose names we know and whose names we do not know.”She added: “I wasn’t sure what I could say to you. I wanted to say the right thing and I was really nervous that it would get picked apart.“And I realised the only wrong thing to say is to say nothing.”Meghan referred to a teacher from the school, who she says gave her the courage to speak out.She said: I was thinking about this moment when I was a sophomore, I was ... it’s the year we do volunteer work.And I remember one teachers, Ms Pollia, said to me, ‘always remember to put other’s needs above your own fears’.That has stuck with me throughout my entire le and I have thought about it more in the last week than ever before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. lockdown measures are lted, people who have been living alone will finally be able to see others indoors and bubble up with them - so they wont have to social distance.It will allow single parents to have extra help from someone outside of their household.The PM said this evening: There are too many people, particularly those who live by themselves who are lonely and struggling with being unable wont be able to meet up indoors in larger groups.People will be able to hug, go into one anothers homes and even stay overnight.They will be treated asthey are part of the same household.If people are bonking ban after measures prohibited people from seeing other people indoors.It means from Saturday lonely Brits will be able to choose one other person to include in their bubble so they dont need title: cop hunt cygnet jogger
story: The cygnet, who died earlier today, was taken into the care of a nearby sanctuary following the attack on Monday evening. The jogger is believed to have kicked the baby bird out of his way instead of going around it. The “desperately poorly” bird was feared to have brain damage before it passed away today.Met Police officers for the Royal Parks have issued an appeal for witnesses.They say the suspect is a white male around  years old, ft in and was wearing black running shorts and a vest at the time. The man has also been described as balding and had a logo on his running top. The Royal Police added in a post to their Twitter page today that the suspect was seen kicking another cygnet “which thankfully managed to escape to the water.”The incident happened around . pm on Monday evening at the Pen Ponds area in the middle of the south-west London park.Police said they spoke to staff at the Swan Sanctuary, based in Shepperton, Middlesex, who said the cygnet was still desperately poorly.The injuries that the bird sustained were described by police as too severe.Did you see this man  Any witnesses should call   and quote reference  .    Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: junk food chains share blame severity coroanvirus pandemic
story: Experts have urged the government to push the food industry to introduce restrictions on the promotion of unhealthy foods.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes as ious studies revealed that people with obesity were at a higher risk of dying from the coronavirus.While other experts urged the government to consider weight loss surgery as a solution to the pandemic.So far in the UK, Covid- has killed over , people and experts have said the government must “seize this opportunity”.In an editorial published in the British Medical Journal, co-author of the study and professor of cardiovascular medicine at Barts and The London Hospital, Graham MacGregor said restrictions could reduce fatalities. Unlike most other risk factors identied for Covid- such as age, sex and ethnicity - obesity is a modiable risk factor.This is why governments worldwide must seize the opportunity to help people to eat more healthily and enforce measures to restrict the promotion, marketing, and advertising of unhealthy foods and ensure their reformulation to contain far less salt, sugar and saturated fat.This would reduce mortality from this vicious virus and many other chronic diseases.The researchers also noted that  per cent of confirmed Covid infections in the UK were made up of people who were overweight.This is while  per cent of deaths in hospitals were also from people who were overweight.Obesity can lead to a number of other serious conditions such as high blood pressure, type  diabetes, heart disease, stroke and cancer.As the virus started to creep into the UK in March and rumours of a lockdown started to circulate, many people started to panic buy.This left shelves in supermarkets across the country empty.Researchers said that this, combined with an increase in food poverty limited the access people had to fresh foods.“This tilts the balance towards a greater consumption of highly processed foods and those with long shelf lives that are usually high in salt, sugar, and saturated fat.The authors claimed the food industry was given a huge free marketing opportunity by the pandemic.They added that the government has “done little” to combat obesity across the country, despite a sugar tax having been introduced.The researchers wrote: Reducing salt, sugar, and saturated fat across the board would improve the diet of the entire population and bring even greater benefits for people who are most socially deprived.The toll of morbidity and mortality from Covid- has made this more apparent and more urgent than ever.The Food and Drink Federationsaid Prof MacGregor’s views on the food industry are well known.Chief operating officer Tim Rycroft said: To blame the food industry for the Covid- mortality rate is deeply offensive. Millions of key workers across the supply chain have continued to work throughout this pandemic and are hidden heroes, keeping Britain fed.He added that manufacturers are fully engaged with a wide range of government-led initiatives designed to tackle the huge public health challenge of obesity.  FDF members’ voluntary work is already delivering substantial changes. Compared to four years ago, FDF member products contribute  per cent less calories,  per cent fewer sugars, and  per cent less salt to the average shopping basket.He said the government needs to invest money in specic measures to support people and areas that are most affected by obesity.We believe a whole lestyle approach will be most effective, focusing on how we achieve a balanced diet and keep active, and not on any single nutrient.” To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus r rate below 1 uk vallance
story: Sir Patrick Vallance said that the value had now fallen in every part of the country and is between . and ..⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut he cautioned that about six to seven per cent of the population is thought to have been infected with Covid- - meaning a vast majority of the population remain susceptible.Referring to data from the Office for National Statistics, he said , were thought to be infected between May  and .Speaking at the daily Downing Street press conference, he said: The R is below one, but perhaps only just below one.The epidemic is shrinking, but not fast. Numbers are coming down but are not yet very low.The vast majority of the population remains susceptible to the infection.That urges caution, it urges going slowly with changes and it urges measuring very carefully to see the impact and being prepared to reverse things where measures have been taken that have an impact on this, and importantly means looking for outbreaks locally and dealing with those fast.The R-number is the average number of people that will contract coronavirus from an infected person.If R is one or higher, the virus will spread exponentially through the population.Researchers had warned the vital number was above one in the North West of England and firmly at  in the South West last week.But earlier this week, Health Secretary Matt Hancock told ministers that R value had fallen - and the virus is in retreat.It comes as Boris Johnson announced that couples kept apart by lockdown restrictions could be reunited and some grandparents will be able to hug their grandchildren from Saturday.The latest move to ease Englands coronavirus lockdown will allow adults living alone or single parents to form a support bubble with one other household.They would then be allowed to mix as though they were one household, spending time together indoors, not having to follow the two-metre rule and would be allowed to stay overnight.Ministers believe the latest easing of the lockdown will help those who have been left isolated while still restricting the spread of coronavirus. The move could allow children in single-parent households to see one set of grandparents.A grandparent living alone would be allowed to visit the house of their child and grandchildren.But the move would not allow a couple to visit both parents as neither household would comprise a single adult.Officials admitted the measure was not going to benefit everyone but was targeted at those who had been left isolated by the lockdown restrictions.At the Downing Street briefing, the Prime Minister said: We are making this change to support those who are particularly lonely as a result of lockdown measures.Its a targeted intervention to limit the most harmful effects of the current social restrictions.It is emphatically not designed for people who dont qualy to start meeting inside other peoples homes, because that remains against the law.Meanwhile the number of deaths involving Covid- in the UK has passed ,, according to analysis of the latest available data.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl bat scratch face rabies jab
story: Shocked Charlene Corcoran, , saw the markings after little Amelie asked her the next morning: “Is the birdie there ”Charlene feared it was a bat because she had woken at am to find something scurrying around her head. title: can spot owl perfectly camouflaged pic
story: The cheeky chap was caught blending perfectly into a tree in India - by a surprised snapper on the search for a leopard.Varun Jain, , a hobbyist photographer from Chennai in southern India, was on safari in Pench National Park in central India. title: sun says government bolder two metre rule schools
story: He has been held back by the intransigence of the unions, parents’ Covid fears and Public Health England’s advice which, as so often, now looks dubious.Labour, true to form, backed the unions over our children, especially the most disadvantaged who are suffering worst.The Left threw up endless roadblocks, claiming it wasn’t safe to .Then, when the Government had little choice but to U-turn on getting all primary kids back before the summer, Labour squealed that a generation was being betrayed. What a hypocritical shambles.But the bigger problem is PHE’s advice to cap class sizes at , making normal school le all but impossible in terms of staffing and space.Its two-metre social-distancing rule is virtually impossible to maintain too, especially in playgrounds.And the reality is that now looks hugely over­cautious and is sabotaging both schools and businesses desperate to reopen.The WHO only recommended one metre. Our scientists doubled it for good measure.Fair enough, perhaps, when infections were soaring.Not now that less than one in , people in England — and falling fast — has Covid.Yes, the virus can kill in extreme circumstances.But our chances of getting it are tiny at two metres and STILL tiny at one.Especially with routine mask use.International studies show reopening schools has barely any effect on increasing infections, among kids or adults.The Government is on the ropes, only prepared to make timid and incremental changes which lead to chaotic and baffling new rules like the new “bubbles” for people living alone.It simply has to be bolder, starting by relaxing the two-metre rule.Now, before it does any more damage.IT’S quite the confession.The same Sage scientists who unanimously advised the Government against an earlier lockdown now say it came too late and may have killed thousands.What, then, should Boris have decided after receiving that advice on March  Perhaps he should have told Britain’s finest epidemiologists: “You clueless clowns don’t know what you’re talking about”, as his prominent critics apparently believe.Instead he deferred to their expertise.Imagine the howling rage of Remainer MPs, journalists and punditsthis Vote Leave Government had not done so.These same champions of hindsight — who had a hissy-fit both over Dominic Cummings attending Sage meetings and over Boris attending too few — now suggest No dithered. But they didn’t.The advice was clear and unanimous. They followed it.The mental gymnastics necessary to blame the Tories for doing both too little and too much, too fast and too slow, would win gold at every Olympics.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: confederate flag united states american south
story: The Civil War, beginning on Apr., , and ending on Apr.,  was fought between the United States of America and the Confederate States of America. Southern states seceded from the Union in the North between -, establishing their own government and conducting their way of le separately.The Confederate flag was designed to signy a ided nation. It went through three iterations before it came to be the one we recognize today that features a red banner, a blue St Andrews cross, and  white stars that represent the Confederate states. It was flown by several Confederate armies, including that lead by Robert E. Lee, who fought to protect slavery as an institution.The confederate flag has been used in the state since . It is the only state in the country whose flag features the confederate symbol.Several public institutions in Mississippi, including Missississippi State University and the University of Mississippi, have opted not to fly the controversial flag in disagreement with what it represents.The last time the state considered changing the flag was back in , where keeping it was put to a vote. % of voters wanted to keep the Confederate emblem as opposed to changing it to  white stars on a blue banner, signying Mississippis establishment as the th state in the USA.The confederacy began as seven Deep South states including Alabama, Louisiana, Georgia, Mississippi, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas.By the time war was declared in , they were joined by Arkansas, Tennessee, Virginia, and North Carolina. The Confederacy was headed by President Jefferson Davis and Vice Pres. Alexander H. Stephens.The confederates seceded from the Union after the election of President Abraham Lincoln in November , who threatened their right to keep slaves. The war began on the premise of slavery—the Confederacy saw slaves as an integral part of their economy.For so many Americans today, the confederate flag now symbolizes the oppression, torture, and terror of their predecessors. In the wake of the Black Lives Matter movement, statues of those historical figures involved in the slave trade like Edward Colston and Robert Milligan are being torn down across the globe.Former governor of South Carolina Nikki Haley once said that the Confederate flag meant “service, sacrice and heritage” for the state.Following a mass shooting where white supremacist Dylan Roof murdered nine Black Americans during an evening bible study in a South Carolina church, Haley deemed that the flag had been hijacked, and it was removed from the South Carolina statehouse ground permanently.A poll by YouGov asked , Americans whether they thought the Confederate flag represented racism or heritage.The results showed % of Americans consider the Confederate flag to represent racism. For % of Americans, however—particularly adults that live in rural communities, non-college-educated white Americans and adults over — the flag represents heritage.In , after the U.S. House banned Confederate flags being flown at war veteran cemeteries, many major retailers like Sears, Wal-Mart, and eBay followed suit and stopped selling the flag. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: steve chalke get kids back to school
story: An incredible army of ­volunteers responded to the call.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNow we need to do the same for our schools.Classrooms have a vital role to play in child development — especially for vulnerable ­children. So we need a strategy. We need leadership, and we need an army of recruits.First, let’s not waste those upcoming summer weeks. There is no need for school to be out for summer.As the Children’s Commissioner Anne Longfield has said, " rel"noreferrer noopener"our schools should be open in some form or other over the six-week summer holidays. We can’t afford to leave it all to the autumn and hope for the best.I am not trying to trap the wonderful teachers into another six weeks without a break. They have already been ­working flat out over the past three months, developing home- learning resources.I understand the practical as well as contractual concerns that need to be negotiated.But without overburdening, or ­risking anyone’s health — where there’s a will, there’s a way.There are teaching staff, ex-teaching staff, retired teaching staff and countless volunteers who I believe are ready and willing to step up and help supervise children under the leadership of professionals.Second, we need to think ­creatively about space.I am the leader of a group of  schools around the country." rel"noreferrer noopener"There is just not enough space in any of our school buildings to properly social- ­distance and house all pupils at the same time.We are not alone here.So let’s use other empty buildings — village halls, town halls, hotel conference halls, church halls and closed museums. What great learning opportunities for “bubbles” — those small groups in which all children are taught now.Third, this moment gives us the opportunity to rethink what education is. If it’s true that we are community beings — that we learn in community from one another — then we need to rethink the curriculum.Education has always been about more than maths, English and geography.It is every little bit as much about social and emotional development.Human beings are social beings. We thrive when we are connected and struggle when we’re not. I talked to a GP who lives up our street and is the mother of an ­intelligent six-year-old boy. She told me last week about how concerned she is about him “becoming withdrawn”. She is right to be worried.We have to get used to the fact that “remote” learning will probably be part of the ­equation for the foreseeable future. So, once again, let’s think dferently.Let’s use the days when children are in school with us dferently to the days when they are at home.Leave the academic subjects for days when they can work at home on projects we have set them the day before. While they are with us, concentrate on team-building and emotional and social skills development, making up for the deficit they have suffered through ­lockdown.Through the summer, let’s use lots of play and sports for the same purpose, along with those “catch-up” lessons. We are all going to have to learn how to balance intelligently “remote” home-learning with the “togetherness” opportunities of classroom learning.In a survey by PiXL — a ­national partnership of primary and secondary schools —  per cent of teachers questioned believed the Covid- crisis presents us with an opportunity for root-and-branch reform of educational methodology.So let’s start now.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: reggie bush usc ban heisman trophy california
story: USC announced the end of the NCAA-mandated ban on Wednesday morning with just four words: Welcome home, Reggie Bush.Yahoo! Sports reported Bush received the news through a letter sent by USC President Carol Folt.I have dreamed of this day for -plus years and Im excited to come home! Bush said, according to the news outlet.As Trojans fans rejoice throughout Calornia, heres why the running back was banned from his alma mater.Bush is a former running back who played college football at USC, where he won the highly coveted Heisman Trophy in  after leading the Trojans to back to back championships in  and .He decided to forgo his senior year of college to enter the NFL Draft in .His stellar career at USC made him the second pick of his draft class, and he was selected by the New Orleans Saints.Bush spent his -year career suiting up for the Saints, Miami Dolphins, Detroit Lions, San Francisco ers and Buffalo Bills before he retired in .He was inducted into USCs Hall of Fame last June, and joined FOX Sports as a college football analyst before the start of the  season.Bushs ban was part of several major penalties USC received from the NCAA after an investigation found he had received forbidden kickbacks from marketing agents as a student.As a result, former college football star forfeited his Heisman Trophy in September .In a statement announcing his decision, he called the bribery allegations dating back to his college years painful and distracting.The Heisman Trophy Trust, which gives out the award, reportedly was close to making a decision on whether to revoke Bushs trophy, according to NPR.Colin Kaepernick, then-quarterback for the ers, said in  he refused to stand for the national anthem during a preseason football game against the Green Bay Packers because of the way black Americans and minorities are treated in the US.I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of color, Kaepernick told NFL media during a post-game interview.To me, this is bigger than football and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way.The -year-old took a knee or sat on the sidelines in protest of racial injustice for all  NFL games during the - season, inciting backlash from NFL fans and even President Donald Trump.Trump called on NFL owners to fire players who protest during the national anthem.Once Kaepernick became a free agent in , he was never signed to another team, sparking rumors that the league blackballed him for his activism.Lilit Avagyan is an Armenian-born dancer.She and Bush tied the knot in July  after dating for three years.The couple are parents to three children: daughter Briseis,, and sons Uriah, , and Agyemang, .The former NFL running back reportedly has a net worth of  million.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teen grandad ww2 bomb shed
story: Ellie Fairclough, , and boyfriend Kayne Davis, , decided to put their free time during lockdown to good use and help her nan sort through the house.But while gathering items to take to the tip, they were stunned to find a three-inch mortar bomb from the Second World War stuffed at the back of the shed in a carrier bag.It’s believed it had been hidden since the early s and put there by Ellie’s grandfather Sandy Wilkinson, .Sandy, passed away last year, was a keen collector and loved to keep any items he could get his hands on - especially WW memorabilia.Ellie said: My grandad always said hed go out with a bang. We’re not sure where he got it from but it must have been sitting there untouched for all those years.“It was just in a normal carrier bag - like the kind you’d get from a supermarket - and right next to it was a bag of ammunition. We couldn’t believe our eyes.”She said after first picking up the item to see what it was, Kane immediately put it down safely and they called the police. Experts from the British Army’s Royal Logistic Corps arrived at the house in Blackpool, Lancs, on Tuesday evening and had to evacuate homes.Ellie said: “It was crazy. One minute we’re cleaning out the shed and the next minute we’re being told to leave our homes because a bomb could potentially go off. Kane was so careful when he put it back in case it exploded.“While we waited for police and bomb disposal experts to arrive, we went out into the street and were chatting to neighbours about it. Everyone was really shocked. We were told to all move to the other side of the street just to be on the safe side.The pair, who have only been dating for a few months, joked that their first photograph together was next to a bomb. Ellie, who lives with her nan Hayley Wilkinson, , said: “I must admit, it’s a good tale to tell. Who knows what  we’ll find hidden in that house.”The bomb and ammunition was taken away by the Royal Logistic Corps.A Lancashire Police spokesman said: “We were called at shortly after .pm on Tuesday following a report that ammunition had been found in the shed of an address in Blackpool. Something has certainly been found but its not entirely clear what it is.They confirmed the EOD were dispatched and the house temporarily cordoned off.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sir geoff palmer keep satues evidence
story: If you remove the evidence you remove the deed.These statues are our history — for both black and white people — so removing them is tampering with the past.Slave traders Edward Colston and Robert Milligan, whose statues have been torn down, are part of black history, which is part of British history.I was born in Jamaica and came to Britain aged  in .People have tried to exclude me but Jamaica has been part of the British story since .I object to the fact that someone would say I’ve got no British connections.I’ve had a long career in academia specialising in the science of brewing and in  became the first black professor in Scotland.I’ve achieved six doctorates and been knighted.Today I’m Jamaica’s Honorary Consul in Scotland.I’m an example of what can be achieved with good people around you and a bit of luck.But I don’t think people’s lives should be dependent on luck.We have prejudices in society that limit representation, education and opportunities for black people.Last year I arrived in Edinburgh to give a lecture and the attendant at the door said: “What do you want ”I said: “l’ve come to give a lecture.” She replied: “When ”I said: “pm.’ She said: “You can’t be because the lecture then is being given by Professor Sir Geoff Palmer.”She’d never seen black people with any status. It’s the system which hasn’t educated her.I don’t think that will change by pulling statues down. You might have made yourself feel better but that’s it.I think in  or  years when black people look back they will realise that part of their history was removed.And white racists don’t mind as it helps people forget slavery.I don’t want people to take my view without asking me because that’s what we’re complaining about with Black Lives Matter.How many people were asked about these actions I have been helping with a plaque for the Melville Monument in St Andrew Square, Edinburgh, which has a statue of Henry Dundas on top.Dundas was a politician who obstructed the abolition of slavery by  years, which meant another , Africans were enslaved.I want to put that under his name.I was on the committee that put up a statue of Mary Seacole in the grounds of St Thomas’ Hospital opposite the House of Commons in London.Mary was a Jamaican-born nurse who cared for British soldiers during the th century Crimean War.London Mayor Sadiq Khan has asked for a review into the city’s statues.I would much rather a committee on removing deprivation.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael schumacher stem cell operation
story: French cardiologist Dr Philippe Menasche, who is known to have operated on the Formula One racing legend before, will perform a pioneering heart op on the German, Italian media reports.French newspaper Le Dauphine reports the latest procedure could take place in the next few days.In , Schumacher suffered a head injury when skiing off-piste in the resort of Meribel in the French Alps.However, his condition has been shrouded in secrecy as he is treated privately by a team of doctors at his home in Geneva, Switzerland.Yet, according to Dr Nicola Acciari, a top neurosurgeon, Schumacher is suffering from osteoporosis and muscle atrophy caused by his lack of movement since his accident.He said: The goal is to regenerate Michaels nervous system.Dr Menasche, who is known as a “pioneer in stem cell surgery”, is reportedly going to carry out another stem cell op on the racing drivers heart.Schumacher, who won a record seven F world championships with Benetton and Ferrari, underwent his first stem-cell therapy in Paris in September last year.French journalist Jean-Michel Décugis told The Times that the stem cell therapy will have an anti-inflammatory effect which will mostly likely impact the brain. He said: Our sources say that Michael Schumacher is receiving stem cell perfusions that... produce a systemic anti-inflammatory effect.That is to say they reach the whole body and you could imagine that they reach Michael Schumachers brain.Its quite mysterious. Officially [Menasché] works only on the heart.He is carrying out experiments with [secretome] that is made by a laboratory from new stem cells and injected into veins, until now only on animals.In October, Menasche warned fans that he does not work miracles following the first widely-reported stem cell therapy on the sports star.He also slammed claims he was carrying out experiments on the legendary racing driver.Speaking with Italian newspaper La Republica, he said: I do not perform miracles.My team and I are not doing an experiment, an abominable term that is not in line with a serious medical view.And after the procedure last year, a nurse told Le Parisien that Schumacher was conscious.She said: Yes he is in my service ... And I can assure you that he is conscious.Speaking about the cutting-edge procedure, Acciari said: Over the past  years, science has made enormous progress with stem cell treatment.But that does not change that we still do not know much about the human brain.We are not able to say what the results will be.In January, Italian brain surgeon Nicola Acciari - who has not reportedly treated the German - claims he will still be changed from the man his millions of fans remember.We must imagine a person very dferent from the one we remember on the track, with a very altered and deteriorated organic, muscular and skeletal structure, said Acciari.All as a result of the brain trauma he suffered, he told Italian newspaper Contro Copertina.Last month, former Ferrari driver Felipe Massa said he is very close to Schumacher and said his situation is not easy.He told Fox Brazil: I know how heis, I have information. My relationship with him has always been very close.It is less close with his we Corinna because she did not go to many races. But I think the main thing about all this is that we know that his situation is not easy. He is in a dficult phase but we need to respect him and the family.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Prime Minister revealed that single people living alone - or with children under  - can form a support bubble with another family or household.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSo what are the rules, and who can you meet, and when The PM said on June : There are too many people, particularly those who live by themselves who are lonely and struggling with being unable to see friends and family.From this weekend we will allow single adult households, living alone, or single parents with children under , to form a support bubble with one other household.Anyone who lives alone at the moment will be able to form a new bubble with another household - of any size - from Saturday, June .It will mean grandparents who live alone can finally see their grandchildren again.And single parents with kids can form a bubble with another house too - so they can stay overnight, help with childcare or provide much needed support.Any lone parent with kids under  is classed as single.The new lockdown changes are thought to affect around to . million people across the country.No. You can visit them in their own home, stay overnight, and you dont need to stay apart.Basically, they can act as though they are a part of your householdYou can travel between their house and yours, or they can move in with your family.No, you can pick only one and see them as much as you like.You cant swap in and out of multiple households.However, you dont have to move in with your new bubble - its OK to travel back and forth to see them.This can technically be as far as you like, but officials stressed that having a local bubble would be better. title: coronavirus fruit picking jobs pay
story: AdvertorialBritish girls reveal the REAL story about being a fruit picker in the UK right nowLucy and Martha signed up to the Pick For Britain campaign, which is helping to save the farming industryShareByDave Masters:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN AdvertorialFruit pickers Marthaand Lucy" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s farms are crying out for fit and healthy temporary workers to keep them going and to help deliver the best quality fruit and veg to the UK. Pick For Britain is a national campaign, bringing workers and employers together to match skills and need to help save the farming industry. The campaign brings all recruiters and those seeking work in one place, from pickers and packers, to plant husbandry and tractor or forklt drivers. Pick for Britain is the perfect chance to pass the summer months and earn moneyyou’re a university student, a way to continue workingyou’re on furlough and a great way to meet new people and be part of an extraordinary national effort to get seasonal food on people’s plates. One British worker who has signed up to work is Lucy, who lives in London. She was travelling in sub-Saharan Africa when the coronavirus crisis began to unfold so ed home and is now doing her bit to Britain in the need for food.  She said: I’m working on one of the iceberg lettuce rigs. I’m staying on site and it’s great - really really enjoying it. it’s a great team atmosphere. You move with the rig across the field, you have to keep up with the pace that the guys are picking it at – itaposs great fun and I’m glad to be doing something useful with my time. I would % recommend it to somebody . I’m having a really good time, the people are really nice, and it’s nice to be out in the open air and doing something physical. Though the work can be demanding, farm work is currently considered key work and it’s a healthy and productive way to support local communities during this dficult time. You usually need to be at least  years old to work on a farm, but there may be roles for  to -year-olds depending on the business and for most roles previous experience is not required, with training given by the farms. Ideally farms are looking for people who can work a full working week but days and hours can y by farm and according to the weather.  Pay depends on your employer and the job you do. You may be paid a set hourly rate or a piece rate which ies depending upon how much you pick.  However, you will always be paid the national minimum living wage  for the average of the hours that you work in a pay period. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSome people will finally be allowed to hug some grandparents in some parts of the UK from Saturday in a major change to lockdown. A single-adult household can form a bubble with one other household and act as though they live together, permanently. It means two households can finally break the two-metre rule to meet, laugh and love for the first time in almost three months. And some separated couples can finally reunite for overnight stays and sex. Boris Johnson announced the shake-up tonight as he unveiled separate changes from June  - including re-opening non-essential shops and zoos. It will be valuable respite to millions whose mental health has been stomped on by lockdown. But critics may warn itaposs far too soon as the UK still notches up hundreds of deaths per day. And the policy is strictly limited to certain situations - with other lockdown rules very much continuing as planned. That means it will leave some bizarre loopholes and many people will feel theyaposre left out. Meanwhile, million people who are shielding will be unable to benefit from forming a bubble with another household, for their own protection. Boris Johnson admitted people will find “anomalies” in “what people can and cannot do” - but that is “just inevitable”. So what exactly has been announced, who can benefit and how  Hereaposs a full explanation. What has Boris Johnson announced   From one minute past midnight this Saturday  June, two separate households in England will be allowed to join together in a “support bubble” under certain conditions. They won’t need to follow the two-metre rule - meaning they can hug, kiss, share childcare and meals, hang out indoors, stay the night and even have sex for the first time since March . “All of those who are in a support bubble will be able to act asthey live in the same household,” a No spokesman confirmed. It will be the first time in three months that dferent households have been given permission to break the two-metre social distancing rule. But there are strict conditions to this and it does not apply to all households.  One of the two households in each bubble must be a “single-adult household”. This means either a person who lives alone, or a single parent who lives with children under . The other household they are joining with can be of any size, and can have more than one adult in it. However, in total each bubble must only consist of two households - and each household must keep the arrangement “exclusive”. That means a person living alone cannot form multiple bubbles with multiple households. Likewise, a family cannot form multiple bubbles with more than one lonely relative. Where does the policy apply  Only in England. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland form their own rules.  Do both households have to be people living alone  No. Only one of the two households being joined together needs to be a “single-adult household”. As long as one household in a bubble fulfils this criteria, the other household is not limited in size.  No. “You can’t switch the household you’re in a bubble with or make a connection with multiple households,” a No spokesman said. This is because it would create chains of transmission that spread the virus through the community. Can aposshieldedapos people form a bubble   No. The million or so people in England who have been told to shielding because they are “extremely clinically vulnerable” cannot form a bubble. They are still advised to keep two metres apart from other households and avoid all social contact - advice which will last at least until June . They can leave the house, but only with members of their own household - orthey live alone, to meet one member of another household from m away. This is likely to create fresh frustration for the millions whoaposve been trapped indoors for medical reasons, living under dferent rules to the rest of the country. A No spokesman said: “Unfortunately we can’t advise anyone who is shielding to form a household bubble. “We do know how hard it is for people who are shielding and we’re keeping the advice under close review, but we’re not able to advise today that they could form a bubble.” Who will this help - and who won’t it help  HELPED: A widow aged  can go round her daughter’s house to stay with her daughter, son-in-law and three grandchildren. NOT HELPED: Two married grandparents, aged  and , can’t visit their daughter’s house to stay with their daughter, son-in-law and three grandchildren. HELPED: A single mum can go stay with her mum and dad to help with childcare. NOT HELPED: Married parents can’t go stay with the we’s mum and dad to help with childcare. HELPED: A -year-old man who lives alone in a bedsit can go stay with both his parents, who are married and live together. NOT HELPED: A -year-old man who lives in a house-share can’t go stay with his parents, who are married and live together. HELPED: A -year-old man who lives with his mates can stay the night with his -year-old girlfriend, who lives alone in her own flat. NOT HELPED: A -year-old man who lives with his mates can’t stay the night with his -year-old girlfriend, who lives with her mates too. HELPED: A lonely widow who wants to reunite with her -year-old daughter can have her round for the night. NOT HELPED: A lonely widow who wants to reunite with her -year-old daughter and -year-old son has to pick one of them to have round for the night. Whatboth sets of grandparents want to come and stay   Then you have a problem. The rules clearly state each household can only have a bubble with one other household. That meansyour maternal grandma and paternal grandma both live alone, and both want to see you… you have to pick one of them. One of them can form a “bubble” with you, come over, hug, eat and stay the night for months to come. The other one you have to see from two metres away in the park or garden. So it won’t help everyone  No. A No spokesman said: “We fully understand this isn’t going to help everyone, but it is a very targeted intervention there to support those who have been particularly isolated by the lockdown.” He added: “We know there are many lonely or isolated people as a result of the pandemic and the lockdown which has been in place and that is a particularly signicant issue for those people who live by themselves. “So we’re making this change to provide those people with additional support.” Does this affect current rules on meeting outside  No. This policy is separate to other current rules in England, which say you can meet in groups of up to six outdoors in a socially distanced way. That rule is unaffected by this new policy which is designed to let people meet indoors. How far away can each household in a bubble be  There is no limit - as long as it’s in England. The government asks people to stay local wherever possible, but understand there will be instances where they can’t do that. You don’t have to move in with the household you’ve formed a bubble with. Whatsomeone in the bubble gets sick  Once you’ve joined together in a “support bubble”, you must treat the rules as though you’re all in the same household. That means the moment one of you develops coronavirus symptoms, everyone in the support bubble must start self-isolating for  days. Will I be punished for setting up two bubbles at once   No. It will be taken on trust, like many of the other more complex lockdown rules. People will not have to fill out forms telling the authorities who they are forming a bubble with. What about children of orced parents  It remains the case that parents who are separated can continue to move children between households and share the care. These households are not prohibited from setting up support bubbles under the system. Put another way, the children of separated parents could potentially be in two support bubbles at once - one bubble for each parent. So does this all mean the end of the sex ban

Sir Keir said the issues facing Downing Street on ensuring pupils were safe toto classrooms were entirely foreseeable and criticised the Prime Minister for failing to meet with opposition parties to put together a plan. There was no plan, no consensus, no leadership, he said in an article for the . Sir Keir said leaving children at home would be damaging not only to their learning but also their welfare. He said: We now have the ridiculous situation where next week betting shops and theme parks will open, but parents are not clear when their children will go back to school. The longer schools are shut, the greater the damage to childrenaposs wellbeing and education and the increasing pressure on parents who are having to juggle childcare and work commitments. The warning from the Childrenaposs Commissioner a few days ago could not have been starker: a generation of children now risk losing out on over six months of education. Bookmakers and non-essential shops are reopening on Monday providing they can safely stick to social distancing guidelines. The criticisms follow on from Sir Keiraposs pointed comments during Prime Ministeraposs Questions, during which he told Boris Johnson that parents had lost confidence in the Governmentaposs schools plan and warned that millions of children could miss six monthsapos worth of education.It is being reported that Boris Johnson is considering dropping the hotly-contested two metre social distancing rule over the summer to free schools to reopen by September.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson was forced to admit defeat this week over plans - set out in the Governmentaposs coronavirus recovery plan - for primary schools to fully reopen.Children in nursery, Reception, Year  and Year  in England began ing to primary school last week after the Government eased lockdown measures. But some schools said they did not have enough space on site to admit all pupils in the eligible year groups, while adhering to Government guidance to limit class sizes to  and encourage fewer interactions. At the Downing Street press conference on Wednesday, Mr Johnson acknowledged he was moving slower than we would have liked in some areas - but he said he wanted all pupils back in classrooms by September. But Sir Keir said that target was in danger of being misseda plan was not put in place soon. Without a plan, there is a risk that even by September many schools will not be able to reopen, and some children could be out of education for an entire year, the former director of public prosecutions said. He argued that creativity needed to be used to utilise the empty buildings across Britain, including theatres, museums and libraries, so they could be repurposed as makesht classrooms.

From midnight on Saturday June , single people living alone in England will be allowed to join together with one other household in a “support bubble” under certain conditions. They won’t need to follow the two-metre rule - meaning they can hug, kiss, share childcare and meals, hang out indoors and stay the night for the first time since March . This means some grandparents who have been separated from their loved ones for months can finally re-unite. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.    However, it doesnapost apply to everyone. A grandparent who lives alone would be able to form a bubble with the household of one of their children, which means they could see them and interact with their grandchildren as normal. But it will not apply to grandparents who live together because one of the two households in each bubble must be a “single-adult household”. This means either a person who lives alone, or a single parent who lives with children under . So grandparents who live together will only be able to see their grandchildrenthey are living with a single parent. The other household they are joining with can be of any size, and can have more than one adult in it. However, in total, each bubble must only consist of two households - and each household must keep the arrangement “exclusive”. This means some grandparents living alone will have to choose between their children and grandchildren that are old enough to no longer live with their parents until restrictions are eased further. Single people living alone will be able to see both their grandparents, but they will then be unable to see any other members of the family as the bubbles must be exclusive.Households with more than one adult can still not mix with one another without observing social distancing and staying outside. Meanwhile, the two million or so people in England who have been told to shield because they are “extremely clinically vulnerable” cannot form a bubble. So grandparents that fall into that category cannot take advantage of the new relaxation, eventhey live alone. The shielded are still advised to keep two metres apart from other households and avoid all social contact - advice which will last at least until June . They can leave the house, but only with members of their own household - orthey live alone, to meet one member of another household from m away.

Chloe Lloyd was driving home from her motheraposs with her eight-year-old daughter Lexi when her Vauxhall Astra left the road and crashed into a tree. She was speaking on a hands-free mobile to her boyfriend Domenico Gugliemucci when he heard a scream before the line went quiet. A worried Mr Gugliemucci rang Miss Lloydaposs mother Emma, who then drove in search of the -year-old and found her daughteraposs body and seriously injured grandchild.  Nurse who died with Covid- developed symptoms after sitting with positive patient Reading out Mr Gugliemucciaposs statement at the Bournemouth inquest, coroner Rachael Grfin said: Chloe said words to the effect of aposhow are you, and you sound tired apos He replied he was fine and asked hershe was driving back from her mumaposs  At which point he heard a scream from Chloe and then other distorted sounds. Then it went quiet, with the only sound the indicators. Miss Lloyd was pronounced dead at the scene on the A at Upton, Poole, Dorset, on January . Her daughter continues to recover from her injuries under the care of her grandparents after receiving emergency treatment in hospital. On the day of the tragic crash, the inquest heard Miss Lloyd had spent time with her mother and daughter before a meal with her father, Martyn. She was last seen alive at around .pm when she set off to drive home. Around  minutes later her parents received the devastating call from Mr Gugliemucci.  A statement from Miss Lloydaposs mother was also read out at the inquest. In the statement Mrs Lloyd said: After the meal Chloe and her father were messing about and joking with one another, as they usually did. She was happy and content and making plans for the future. A post mortem examination show Miss Lloyd, who held a driving licence for  years and had no endorsements, died from multiple injures. Further tests showed she had no alcohol or drugs in her system, and did not have any underlying health conditions. A police investigation found the car had no mechanical defects and that all four tyres were in a serviceable condition. Miss Lloydaposs mobile phone was in her handbag inside the car, connected to her hands-free system via bluetooth, police found. No other vehicles were involved in the collision and witness statements said that Miss Lloydaposs car just lost control, spun around and then careered off the carriageway and collided with the tree. Road conditions were good and police found no evidence of any object in the carriageway or even any animal in or by the side of the road.  Ms Grfin said: Iaposm satisfied from all the evidence before me that the cause of her death is as the result of injuries that Miss Lloyd sustained in a road traffic collision. Following a thorough investigation by Dorset Police they did not find any reason why Miss Floydaposs vehicle left the carriageway that day. She was not driving at excessive speed. There is no physical evidence to account for why her vehicle left the carriageway that day. I know that Chloe was on the phone, but it is clear she was acting within the law and using a hands-free device to make that call. That phone call was very short, her phone was found within her bag - so there was no evidence to suggest she had handled that telephone to make a call.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Natalie Poole arrived on the remote island of Kyun Pila in Myanmar on March  and planned to spend the next month working as a volunteer to help protect a coral reef - but then coronavirus hit.The -year-old, from Ashburton in Devon, is now trapped in a real le castaway drama after her only boat off the island was cancelled as Myanmar and nearby Thailand both went into lockdown. For the last two months, Natalie and four other volunteers have been forced to survive almost without any aid in one of the worldaposs most remote locations. Natalie and her fellow volunteers were due to be rescued on May  but were left devastated again when their boat was cancelled after Thailand extended its lockdown. The scuba er instructor, who should be back in Devon by now and working as a summer school teacher, is hopeful another boat will arrive to collect them later this month. However, her visa has expired and no new ones are being issued while the coronavirus pandemic holds the world in its grip. Natalie said: The hardest thing for me has been not knowing how long weaposre going to be here. Itaposs kind of up and down, weaposre a very small group of people and weaposre living in a very confined, close situation. In the back of our minds is obviously families back home and stuff, which adds to the tension a little bit. Weaposre just trying to take things day by day. But for now, the tiny group have had to do what they can to survive, using washed up bits of plastic to make their rainforest camp. They share the island with scorpions, snakes, mouse-deer, wild boar, monitor lizards, and slow lorises, and have to forage for most of their food, including yams, jackfruit and other vegetation. There have been sporadic deliveries by boat of food staples, including rice and pasta. But the group are conscious they have to make sure these last as they donapost know when the next one will arrive - and there have been plenty of days where they have gone hungry. Natalie said: We have to be very aware of how much we consume, we are eating very basic food and really having to make it last. Despite the desperate situation the group, which is made up of two women and three men from England, Hungary, Canada, Malaysia and France, find themselves in - they are not totally alone. There is one resort on Kyun Pila, Awei Pila, which is a  minute dinghy sail away and where they can access water, showers and accomodation on portable cabins, as well as a patchy wi signal. This has proved a leline for Natalie, who is concerned for her -year-old father, who lives in Poole in the UK. But the group, who are volunteers with environmental group Ocean Quest Global, have had to adapt quickly to spending so much extra time on the island. Their jungle camp has been constructed from washed up plastic, with each person living in a hut made from bamboo, rice sacks and bottles. They have even managed to erect furniture in their new Robinson Crusoe-inspired le, have dug a well, a fire pit and place to wash.The volunteers have also started planting their own vegetables. There are other challenges for the small group, existing in such extreme circumstances. Natalie explained: Usually in a programme like this there is a regular change of volunteers, which keeps things fresh and interesting, but the other three volunteers have been with each other a long time now and relationships are strained at times. Communal living is always a challenge because you get so little personal space and have to compromise a great deal. One person’s negative attitude or bad mood will affect everyone. The group has been forced to adapt to their change in circumstances, with people learning to hack jungle trails, drive a dingy and build with bamboo. Natalie has earned herself the nickname Trash Squirrel by spending her days combing the beach for washed up waste that can then be put to use to build the structures theyaposre calling home and to be turned into useful tools for surivival. But as spring slowly turns into summer Natalie and her fellow volunteers are facing a new challenge - the tropical rainy season. Already the clouds are coming in faster and the first few drops of rain have started to fall. They are working to do all they can to ensure they are as ready as possible for when the downpours do come.  However, Natalie is still hopeful that a rescue boat will come for them before the rainy season begins in earnest. She says it has also been a useful time for getting to know herself better. Natalie explained: I learned that no matter how Zen and chilled I had thought I was, in moments of solitude and dficult moments of physical and mental tiredness, I still lose control and stop being mindful and calm. That no matter how friendly and cheerful I usually am, when I am locked down on a relatively small island with strangers, I become moody, grumpy and little motivated.

The overriding aim of the project is to bring together an unofficial national archive of the crisis, what has touched our everyday lives, the heroes behind the stories and images.
