title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: selkirk-rugby-players-bid-clean-town
story: HAVING just completed a sponsored charity project that raised almost pound, in under a fortnight for the townrsquos foodbank, Selkirk Rugby Clubrsquos players arenrsquot letting the grass grow under their feet.This week members of the clubrsquos playing squad have embarked on yet another lsquochallengersquo to support the local community ndash litter collection.The idea came from former st XV skipper Ross Nixon, and comes in the wake of a similar venture undertaken by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo professional players.ldquoWhen yoursquore walking in and around Selkirk, you canrsquot help noticing pieces of litter that have been left lying around, often when proper bins arenrsquot that far away, said Nixon.ldquoI thought it would be a good idea for Selkirk players to take a bin bag with them when they head out to take their daily exercise, picking up any litter they see next to paths or along roadside verges.ldquoWersquore lucky in Selkirk to have such unspoilt countryside to exercise in, so itrsquos a shame to see it spoiled by discarded empty bottles, food wrappers and general rubbish.ldquoI kicked off the campaign by nominating three members of our players ndash Aaron McColm, Ewan MacDougall and Liam Cassidy ndash to collect litter on their walks.ldquoEach of this trio will then challenge a further three players to collect litter, and in turn these three will nominate other team-mates, and so on.The project has the backing of Selkirk head coach Scott Wight.He said: ldquoItrsquos another way the club can put something back into the local community, though this time therersquos no sponsorship involved.ldquoItrsquos looking asitrsquos going to be a wee while before any rugby is going to be played, so this latest effort not only helps keep the players in touch with each other, itrsquos also providing a useful service for the Selkirk community.Meanwhile, Selkirk Rugby Club is to stage its annual Players Presentation Night on Fridayndash although this yearrsquos event will be a lsquovirtualrsquo get-together.The plan is for the clubrsquos coaches, players and rugby officials to be digitally linked via Zoom, with Selkirk head coach Scott Wight taking charge of proceedings.ldquoThe idea is to try and stick as closely as possible to the format normally used at the clubrsquos annual presentation nights, said Wight.ldquoA total of nine trophies are up for grabs, and the name of each award winner will be announced separately on the video link, followed by film footage, or photos, of that player in a match situation.ldquoShort addresses will be given by, among others, the clubrsquos chairman and its director of rugby, as well as recaps of the st and lsquoArsquo XVsrsquo seasons by the sidesrsquo respective team managers."It should be a fun evening!

title: rugby-players-hailed-helping-prepare-golf-course
story: GALA rugby players have been thanked for helping to prepare a local golf course for reopening.Torwoodlee Golf Club welcomed members back on Fridayafter First Minister Nicola Sturgeon eased lockdown restrictions.Club chairman Robin Brydon said greenkeepers had been helped by Gala RFC players.He thanked the volunteers for their "great efforts" in rolling turf and raking bunkers.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoWersquod be delighted to help other local sports clubs and organisations in these times ndash get in touch."You can contact the rugby club through its Facebook page or by emailing info@galarfc

title: i-worry-seizure-even-though-medicine-works
story: A GALASHIELS schoolgirl with epilepsy has made a video to teach people about the condition.Lucy Millar gets seizures lasting up to  seconds due to childhood absence epilepsy .Now the nine-year-old wants to teach people how to react when someone has a seizure.Her father Bruce said he felt "pretty emotional" as his daughter crafted a YouTube video, which has gone on to achieve more than , views."Right from the start she wanted to reach as many people as possible to teach them about CAE ," said Mr Millar, whose daughter was diagnosed a year ago.Lucy said: "I feel more OK about it [CAE] because I know more about epilepsy now."Sometimes I worry that Ill have a seizure even though I know my medicine works."I dont think many people know there are dferent types of epilepsy andmore people know about it then its better for epileptics."I would like to teach people what to dosomeone they know has an absence seizure to make sure they are safe."Also to help people spot absence seizures with their children."This newspaper asked Mr Millar what advice he would give parents whose children have epilepsy.He said: "Take a deep breath ndash you might feel like youve been hit by a train, but theres a good chance your child is braver than you realise."He also recommended joining support groups and letting children with epilepsy socialise together.To watch Lucys video, you can click this link.

title: mcdonalds-galashiels-site-reopens-drive-thru
story: McDONALDS in Galashiels has reopened its drive-thru service after closing due to the coronavirus pandemic.Safety measures are in place at the Wilderhaugh site, which is running with reduced staff.The drive-thru opened at am today with a limited menu.McDonalds says it expects a "high demand" at all of its reopened sites.The fast food chain has issued a list of the safety measures being rolled out.These are the new measures at McDonaldsSocial distancing in kitchens and service areasPerspex screens at drive-thru windowsProtective equipment for staffFloor markings in the premisesAll staff will be asked to confirm they are healthy and able to work andcontactless thermometers will be used to take employees temperatures on arrival for every shtRestaurants willwith smaller teams, offering a limited menuand operating reduced hoursEncouraging capped spendat pound per order, with customers encouraged to pay by contactless methodsDrive-thru customers can browse the menu, order and pay ahead using the My McDonaldrsquos app

title: scots-urged-take-knee-doorsteps-solidarity-george-floyd-tonight
story: People across Scotland are being asked to show their solidarity with George Floyd on their doorsteps this evening as protests in America continue.Anti-racism campaigners Stand Up to Racism are urging people to take the knee on Wednesday night in a socially-distanced protest in response to the death of Floyd, who died in police custody.The -year-old died last week after a police officer held him down by pressing his knee into his neck.The US has since erupted in riots from people demanding justice, and other countries across the world have begun to take action.People in the UK are being asked to kneel at their doorsteps at pm on Wednesday.They say the demonstration has been inspired by the kneeling protests first staged by American football star Colin Kaepernick in .ldquoWe send our condolences, and stand in solidarity with all those demanding justice right now from deaths resulting from contact with the policemdashfrom Minnesota to Kirkcaldy," said Talat Ahmed, STUCs Scotland Convenor."As we demand justice for George Floyd we also remember Sheku Bayoh, who like Floyd said, I cant breathe, while being brutally restrained by police five years ago here in Scotland."We welcome the First Ministers support for the Black Lives Matter movement. But we also support the call from the Scottish Trades Union Congresss Black Workers Committee on the Scottish government for more openness about the impact of coronavirus on BAME communities here in Scotland."We call on Scottish MPs to back the EDM at Westminster for a public inquiry into the disproportionate impact of Covid- on BAME communities."Several protests had been organised throughout Scotland, however First Minister Nicola Sturgeon advised protesters to avoid large groups.Ms Sturgeon backed the Black Lives Matter movement, saying she sympathised with those looking to protest, but warned of the risks involved with gathering due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.She said: "Right now, it is the case, unfortunately, and regrettably, that large gatherings of people could pose a risk to health and indeed to le."Unfortunately, thats the case whether it is a peaceful protest or a football match or any other gathering where people are coming together in close proximity."What I would say to those who want to protest, and I say this as an ally and supporter, is that we need to find ways of allowing people to make their voices heard and to make the points that many of us want to be made and to be heard right now but to do so in a way that is safe and is not putting people protesting or wider communities at risk."

title: ibuprofen-tested-possible-treatment-reduce-covid-19-symptom
story: Scientists have begun a new trial to determine whether ibuprofen might hold the key to preventing severe breathing problems inCOVID- patients.Heres what you need to know.Why has the new trial started Experts are assessing whether a special formulation of thedrug could help reduce the serious side effect seen among patients infected withcoronavirus.It is hoped that the cheap anti-inflammatory drug could reduce severe respiratory illness when delivered at a certain point tohospital patients.This could potentially lead to shorter hospital stays and fewer patients needing help in intensive care units .The trial is for hospitalised patientsMitul Mehta, professor of neuroimaging and psychopharmacology and director of Centre for Innovative Therapeutics at Kings College London, told the PA news agency: ldquoItrsquos a trial for patients with COVID- disease to seegiving them an anti-inflammatory drug ndash a specic form of ibuprofen ndash will reduce the respiratory problems they have.He stressed that the trial was for hospitalised patients ndash not those who have mild or suspected COVID-.Participants will be drawn from those who are hospitalised, but not so ill they are in need of intensive care.ldquoAndwe can reduce their symptoms at that stage we have a number of benefits: we could reduce the amount of time that someone spends in hospital ndash they might recover quicker and go home, thatrsquos obviously a fantastic outcome we also might be reducing the degree of respiratory distress so that it can be managed in the hospital setting, without needing to go to ICU. And that is a fantastic outcome as well.ldquoTheoretically, this treatment, given at this time, should be beneficial.ldquoBut of course, this is based on animal studies. Itrsquos based on case reports, we need to do a trial to show that the evidence actually matches what we expect to happen.What have other studies found so far Prof Mehta said that animal studies into acute respiratory distress syndrome ndash a symptom of COVID- disease ndash showthat about  per cent of animals with this condition die.But when they are given this special formulation of ibuprofen, the survival rates increase to  per cent.ldquoThis is very promising, he added. ldquoBut of course it is an animal study, so we want to translate that really compelling result into humans.How will the trial work The Liberate trial is a joint effort between experts from Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust, Kingrsquos College London and the pharmaceutical organisation the SEEK Group.Half of the patients enrolled in the trial will receive standard care and the other half will receive standard care plus the special ibuprofen formulation.,params: .pushIt is hoped that the way the drug has been formulated will reduce potential gastric side effects linked to ibuprofen.Professor Matthew Hotopf, director of the NIHR Maudsley Biomedical Research Centre, said: ldquoThis highly innovative therapeutic approach seeks to rapidly advance a potentially important new treatment."If successful, the global public health value of this trial result would be immense given the low cost and availability of this medicine.Early on in the pandemic, there was controversy over the use of ibuprofen after a French health minister advised against the use of it.Scientists in Britain launched a review to assess ties to the drug and COVID-.The Commission on Human Medicinesrsquo expert working group concluded: ldquoThere is currently insufficient evidence to establish a link between use of ibuprofen and susceptibility to contracting Covid- or the worsening of its symptoms.

title: peebles-callants-keep-town-looking-good-annual-clean
story: DESPITE this years Beltane Festival being cancelled due to coronavirus, the Callants still turned out to keep Peebles clean and "looking good".Around  volunteers gathered on Sundayat am to remove weeds and litter across central areas of the town.The clean-up, held before the Beltane each year, collected more than  bags of weeds this time round.The High Street, Eastgate, Northgate and the Old Town were all looked after by the volunteers, who were armed with garden tools, gloves and high-vis vests.Chief Callant Andrew Williamson told the Peeblesshire News: "This year, because of lockdown, council workers are not out, so the town has more weeds than usual."We had one or two comments online so we brought the clean-up forward."We would usually do it the Sunday before Beltane."Mr Williamson, , said Tweed Bridge and Cuddy Bridge also received the clean-up treatment a fortnight ago.He added that after both events, the town is now "looking good".Across the Borders, summer festivals have been cancelled, including West Lintons Whipman Play and Innerleithens St Ronans Border Games.The Chief Callant described how he felt about the cancellation of this years celebrations.He said: "Its disappointing, but there is not much we can do."The last time the festival stopped was probably World War Two."But every festival is the same. Well have to come back next year bigger and better than before."Updates on the Beltane Festival  can be found on the festivals Facebook page at: www.facebook PeeblesBeltaneFestival

title: tourists-slammed-driving-borders-making-diy-loo
story: CITY residents have been accused of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for Peebles by travelling to the town and breaching lockdown rules.The chairman of Peebles Community Council says visitors from Edinburgh were spoken to by police at the weekend.Les Turnbull said: ldquoI am disappointed that the police did not take more positive action to prosecute these offenders.Relaxed lockdown measures were introduced last Friday , allowing Scots to meet up with one other household outdoors as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight people and everyone stays two metres apart.Travelling short distances for leisure and exercise is permitted, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon recommending that no-one goes further than five miles from their home.However, Mr Turnbull says police spoke to visitors from Edinburgh at the weekend after reports that three vehicles had parked up in Hay Lodge Park, Peebles, next to Fotheringham Bridge.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt would appear that the occupants of these vehicles had removed the chain securing the gate in South Parks Industrial Estate to gain access before parking up and erecting what appeared to be a makesht toilet behind a screen.Police are understood to have issued advice to the group, who claimed they had found the gate open. They packed up and left soon after being spoken to.Mr Turnbull said: ldquoIt beggars belief that these visitors from Edinburgh feel they can drive to Peebles, go through a gate which is chained, and park up on what is clearly park land.ldquoTo then erect what seems to be a toilet on the grass near Fotheringham Bridge really is a step too far.ldquoWhere any of this human waste was dumped, is a question I would like answering.Mr Turnbull says he has asked council officials to make sure the gate is secured with a ldquoheavy padlock.The community leader believes misbehaving visitors are guilty of showing a ldquocomplete disregard for the regulations and the people of Peebles.He added: ldquoAs the town begins to recover from this crisis, we do want and need visitors to come and enjoy what we have to offer, but is it too much to ask for them to be respectful and responsible Chief Inspector Stuart Reid said: "The current regulations are clear: people should only leave the house for very limited purposes, for example for basic necessities, for exercise or recreation, for medical needs or travelling for work which cannot be done from home."We are asking people to take personal responsibility to do the right thing and remember the purpose of these measures is to aid the collective effort to protect the NHS and save lives by preventing the virus from spreading."Our officers will continue to engage with the public, explain the legislation and guidance and encourage compliance."We will use enforcement as a last resort only where there is a clear breach of the legislation."

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The UKis to be graced by a Strawberry Moon this week in a rare lunar event that will lightup the skies.The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST on Friday evening.According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three tofour days.

title: coronavirus-make-face-mask
story: YOUVE probably heard by now that wearingface coverings in Scotlands public placescould become mandatory in the future.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this was under consideration in her daily briefing yesterday, but stressed there is no timescale on when the wearing of one mightenforced across the country.Ms Sturgeon was keen to emphasise medical face masks should be prioritised for frontline workers and instead has encouraged Scots to make their own face coverings from home.Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:Elastic band or hair tiesBandanaHandkerchiefT-shirtScissorsKitchen towelPinsNeedle and threadWhat are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all timesStore used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash themWash a face covering regularly - it can go in with other laundry, using your normal detergentThe one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.,params: .pushHeres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: borders-builder-saves-35-jobs-bank-loan
story: A BORDERS builder has saved  jobs after receiving a six-figure loan.Melroses Rural Renaissance Ltd , the parent company of JS Crawford, put  full-time staff on furlough due to the coronavirus shutdown.But the workers futures are now safe after Bank of Scotlandagreed to issue a loan.The banks relationship director Douglas Spowart said: "The funding has secured the future of the business alongside the jobs of its  members of staff.JS Crawford Group is one of the largest builders in the region, with sites in Melrose, Kelso and Galashiels.RRL managing director Michael Crawford said: ldquoWe were set for further success this year until the COVID- crisis hit."As with many other businesses, much of our activity is now on hold.ldquoThe financial support means wersquove been able to pay our suppliers and support our staff.ldquoWersquore a big part of the community here, so itrsquos really important to us as a company that wersquore able to meet our commitments.Once lockdown has ended, the firm aims to start three projects in the Borders.Seven large houses are planned for Orchard Park, Gattonside, while Galashiels is due to see a mix of detached and semi-detached homes at the Old Tennis Courts on Abbotsford Road.Luxury flats and a health spa, planned for Melrose, are awaiting planning permission.Mr Crawford said the bank has helped RRL through "cash flow challenges, ensuring we have the financial headspace needed to continue to trade".Mr Spowart, of the bank, added: ldquoWersquove worked with RRL to put a package in place that, critically, the business can afford to repay."RRL achieved a turnover of pound million in .

title: borders-urged-stay-within-five-miles-home
story: BORDERS residents are being reminded that they should stay within five miles of their home under the updated lockdown guidance.Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan has thanked people for staying at home as much as possible during the coronavirus pandemic.But Ms Logan is urging households to remain within five miles of their front doorthey do travel for exercise or recreation.She said: ldquoWhile we have so many beautul places to visit in our region, Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.Lockdown rules were relaxed slightly on May , meaning people can now meet up with one other household outside, as long as the total gathering contains no more than eight and everyone follows social distancing guidelines.Ms Logan said: ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom, Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.Meanwhile, NHS Borders chief executive Ralph Roberts also thanked residents for obeying guidelines so far.He said this has helped drive down the number of virus patients in the region, adding that the health board has ldquosignicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for such patients.However, Mr Roberts said circumstances can ldquoeasily change.He said: "COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends.The full statement from Tracey Logan"Weve only been able to reach this stage thanks to our residents staying at home, only making essential journeys, observing social distancing guidelines and washing their hands regularly."I want to thank everyone for playing their part."We can now meet up with other households outdoors and I know families and friends across the Borders have been making the most of the opportunity to see each other again."You do still need to keep at least two metres apart, though, stay outdoors, and wash your hands regularly."People are now allowed to sit in parks and open areas, and travel within their local area for exercise or recreation."While we have so many beautul places to visit in our region Id strongly advise everyone to follow the national guidelines by not travelling more than five miles from your home.ldquoWhile we can now enjoy slightly more freedom Irsquod still encourage you to stay at home as much as possible to help limit the spread of the virus.ldquoWe have been able to ease restrictions on some services such as reopening community recycling centres but other council facilities such as playparks and public toilets remain closed.ldquoI also know residents who are currently shielding are being asked to remain at home for the time being."I realise the sacrices these people are having to make but would like to reassure them that we will continue to give them all the support they need."Our Community Assistance Hubs can provide help with food, shopping and delivery of medication as well as regular check-ins to see that everything is okay."If anyone needs support please visit our website or call   .The full statement from Ralph RobertsldquoI would like to take the opportunity to thank everyone in the Borders for the co-operation you have shown over the last two months in following the guidance on lockdown and restriction of movement."All of us in the NHS are very conscious that this has been dficult and will have had a lasting impact on many people in our community."However, I am pleased to emphasise that this has worked so far and as a local NHS we have been able to care for all the COVID patients we have seen, whether that was in the community or for those more seriously ill in hospital."I am also pleased to advise that over the last month we have seen a steady reduction of patients in hospital who have had or been suspected of having COVID."We have therefore now signicantly reduced the number of beds set aside for COVID patients."However I recognise that this can easily change and I would therefore encourage everyone to continue to follow the Scottish Government advice as we ease lockdown.,params: .push"Please also remember to follow the advice on hand hygiene, physical distancing and self-isolationyou or a family member is experiencing any symptoms of the virus."COVID- has already claimed too many lives and we all have a responsibility to ensure that we do everything we can do to protect our local community, family and friends."We are now working hard to look at how we can reintroduce the services we needed to pause while we responded to COVID."Because of the continuing risk with COVID this will mean though that some of our services will be provided dferently so that we can keep our patients and staff safe."I would therefore ask that you follow any information or requests that are madeyou need to attend one of our healthcare premises."Please remember that the NHS is open and should you have any concerns about your health please do not hesitate to contact us through the normal routes."UPDATE -.pm, June , -The words for exercise or recreation have been added to the end of the third paragraph of this article.

title: many-key-workers-borders
story: KEY workers make up more than a third of the Borders workforce, statistics show.The term lsquokey workerrsquo describes a person who is essential to the coronavirus response, including health and social care staff, supermarket employees and delivery drivers.Figures published by the Office for National Statistics show the Borders was home to a total of , key workers in .The figure equates to . per cent of the regionrsquos workforce ndash a slightly greater proportion than the UK average .Across Scotland and the rest of the UK, health and social care staff make up the greatest proportion of key workers.A separate analysis by jobs website Check-a-Salary shows the average salary for a full-time key worker in Scotland is pound,.For comparison, a person working  hours a week on the real Living Wagegets paid pound,.

title: premier-league-amazon-bbc-bt-sky-reveal-tv-schedule-upcoming-matches
story: TV channels and streaming s have revealed their schedules for the remaining Premier League football matches.The Premier League will resume on June  after a -day hiatus because of the title: staff-face-redundancy-top-borders-hotel
story: STAFF at a leading Borders hotel are at risk of losing their jobs.Crieff Hydro Group, which operates the four-star Peebles Hydro, has announced that  jobs are under threat across its portfolio.The grouprsquos chief executive Stephen Leckie says he is ldquopersonally devastated for everyone who could lose their job.As reported by our sister newspaper The Herald, Mr Leckie said coronavirus has had a ldquodrastic impact on his hotels.He said: "When we closed our doors at the end of March, it was one of the darkest days in our  year history and this is another.ldquoThe impact coronavirus has had on our industry and business has been immediate and drastic.ldquoAs a family-run business built on the strength of our people, discussing potential redundancies is the toughest step wersquove ever had to consider.ldquoI am personally devastated for every one of our team who could lose their job."The Crieff Hydro Group says it will start a consultation with affected staff in August.

title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has confirmed todayshe is "optimistic" that Scotland will be able to enter Phase  of the routemap out of lockdown next week.The First Minister said morecoronavirus lockdown measures are set to be eased "at least in part" at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that,  days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhat can change next week While not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygiene measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants can open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - as long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab andresearch facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNzpic tjtWumdash Jack AitchisonMay ,

title: mcdonalds-glasgow-set-open-walk-ins-month---
story: McDonaldrsquos bosses have revealed when their Scotland stores will reopen for walk-ins.Following a closed test in London last month,  service station locations on UK motorways will open for takeaway from Wednesday, June .Then, from June onwards, they will gradually roll-out to high streets, towns and city centres.The fast-food chain also plan a trialled relaunch of the McDonaldrsquos breakfast service from that date.McDonaldrsquos UK  Ireland CEO Paul Pomroy said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be back.ldquoI am extremely proud of our employees, franchisees and suppliers who are working so hard in so many communities already.ldquoThe high street is at the heart of our business, it is where we started in the UK, in Woolwich over  years ago.ldquoIn line with Government changes to lockdown restrictions, over the next few weeks and months wersquoll reopen on high streets across the UK and in towns and cities in Ireland.ldquoI know that opening those doors will be incredibly satisfying for our restaurant teams, but it will also mean them getting used to the measures we have implemented to enable us to safely .ldquoSo please continue to support them and follow the social distancing measures wersquove introduced for the safety of our teams and you.What do McDonaldrsquos say about new safety measures -We will provide clear signposting and floor-markings to create a one-way system around our restaurants for you and our delivery partner couriers-We will only allow certain numbers of people inside our restaurants at a time to help you and us adhere to social distancing ndash this will y depending upon the restaurant size and lay-out-When you visit us for takeaway, we will welcome you inside when a space becomes available, and wersquoll ask you to sanitise your hands at the cleaning stations we are introducing in all restaurants-We will have fewer self-order screens switched on and will sanitise those in use at least every  minutes. You can also order via the My McDonaldrsquos app-If you can visit alone to collect your food, please do so, however we know this isnrsquot always possible ndash children are of course still welcome, but for now wersquoll be putting away our crayons and colouring sheets and keeping the play areas and digital play areas closed-Our seating areas, customer toilets and lts will remain closed-As our dining areas will not be open, our recycling points will also remain closed but most of our packaging can be recycled so please do dispose of it responsibly and recycle wherever possible when you get home-To help protect our employees and other customers, we ask you not to visityou feel unwell.

title: dentists-plan-reopen-glasgow-practices-open-doors-england
story: A PHASEDto face-to-face dental services could be introduced in Scotland by next week.Currently all practices are closed apart from telephone triage, with increased care offered at emergency dental hubs and urgent dental care centres.Scotlandrsquos Chief Dental Officer Tom Ferris laid out reopening plans in a letter published yesterday.He writes that the the Scottish Government hopes to reintroduce services ldquoon a phased basis over the course of this month.The precise date will be confirmed at the next three-weekly review of lockdown regulations, which takes place on June  ndash with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon already confirming she is ldquooptimistic the country will move into Phase  of the route map out of lockdown on that date.So, what does this mean If Scotland does indeed move into Phase  from June , then all dental practices would be permitted to open to see patients with ldquourgent care needs from this point ndash provided they are non-aerosol generating procedures.Mr Ferris, however, notes that ldquonot all dental practices will be able to open at the same time as some practices may take longer to prepare".He continued: ldquoThe start date is not to be considered a target ndash practices must be certain they can safely open before they do.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNzpic NojpLpSdcmdash Jack AitchisonMay , What about Phase  and From Phase , which is a currently  date but could be as soon as mid-July, all dental practices can reopen to see registered patients, even without ldquourgent needs.And from Phase , there will be a limited introduction of aerosol generating proceduresto dental practices, which will be dependent on evidence of risk and possible mitigation.How does this compare to England #Dental practices in England were permitted to reopen yesterday for the first time since lockdown rules were introduced.There, the British Dental Associationhas told practices to prioritise patients with urgent need and vulnerable groups when resuming services, with an increase in demand expected to work through the backlog.But not all dentists down south were happy with the decision ndash in a warning that could be a sign of things to come in Scotland.They want the UK Government to provide further support, saying so far it has been ldquotoo limited.One dentist has described theto work as ldquonerve-wracking.The BDA union has asked for dentists to be granted key worker status and access to the Government supply chain on PPE, as one industry survey suggests only around one third of surgeries in England opened yesterday.

title: interview-borders-book-festival-prepares-go-online
story: CELEBRITY guests have been a staple of the Borders Book Festival since its launch in .Clearly, festival founder Alistair Moffat has no shortage of impressive contacts to draw upon.Yet some readers might be surprised to learn the identities of the pair he would most like to see in Melrose.ldquoAnt and Dec, blurts Moffat, , without a momentrsquos hesitation.Describing the Geordie duo as ldquogreat guys, he says: ldquoIrsquove been trying to persuade them and they know Irsquoll never give up ndash and theyrsquoll crumble one day.This year, though, there will not be a famous face in sight within the walled gardens of Harmony House.With coronavirus restrictions putting paid to any chance of a physical gathering, the showcase ndash which was originally planned for this weekend ndash is set to take a virtual form.Beginning on July , authors will star in events available for streaming from the festival website.Moffat is still in the middle of booking guests, but he has already snapped up some well-known figures, as ever.ldquoIn a way, itrsquos easier for people, he says, ldquobecause all they have to do is sit in front of their laptop camera ndash they donrsquot have to come to Melrose.Itrsquos now looking more likely than not that Moffat and his fellow directors will triumph over the obstacles posed by COVID-.But back in March, when the virus began to take hold in Britain, a sense of despondency hung over the group.ldquoWe were absolutely heartbroken, because virtually all of our work had been done by then, says Moffat.As it became clearer that a physical event would not be possible, Moffat and his colleagues realigned their ambitions and channelled their energies into simply making sure that the festival would survive.To Moffatrsquos relief, the idea of an online version found favour with sponsors and the Friends of the Festival.ldquoOnly three people wanted their money back and whatrsquos amazing is we had a tsunami of supportive emails from the public, says Moffat, calling the response ldquovery moving.Everyone will be able to watch the streamed events without paying a penny, says Moffat, with viewers merely invited to make a donationthey can afford it.ldquoSome festivals have charged for these things, but we donrsquot think thatrsquos right, says Kelso-born Moffat, himself an author of more than  books.ldquoWersquoll invite people to donatethey wish, but these are hard times ndash people need to put food on the table.Notwithstanding his delight at being able to run the festival this year, despite the dficult conditions, Moffat is already looking forward to theof a physical format.ldquoTherersquos nothing like being in the same place as Melvyn Bragg or Joanna Lumley or Gordon Brown and being able to ask them questions, says Moffat.,params: .pushThe appeal of the Borders Book Festival, according to its founder, lies in the eventrsquos ldquosociability.ldquoThe famous people are not all herded off into a sealed container ndash theyrsquore there to talk to you, says Moffat.ldquoPeople who are extremely well-known, that all peels away and wersquoll see them standing chatting.Which brings us neatly to comedy twosome Ant and Dec, the showbiz stars whose presence Moffat so dearly craves.ldquoWhat people would see from Ant and Dec is just something completely dferent, he says, admiringly, having known the TV personalities for many years.The pair have a book coming out this year, according to Moffat ndash so perhaps his dream might yet come true.Full details of the virtual events, set to run for  weeks, will be published at: www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: black-lives-matter-yorkshire-tea-pg-tips-went-viral
story: The UKs largest tea brands have gone viral online after responding to Twitter users who spoke out against Black Lives Matter.The Black Lives Matter movement has been gaining traction in the UK following protests in America.This is everything you need to know about what happened.What did Yorkshire Tea say As momentum around the Black Lives Matter movement continues to grow, ious brands have been voicing their support.Until now, popular tea brand Yorkshire Tea has remained quiet on the matter.A far-rightvlogger wrote on Twitter: ldquoIrsquom dead chuffed that Yorkshire Tea hasnrsquot supported BLM with a smiling face emoji.The tweet quickly gained the attention of Yorkshire Tea, who wrote back: ldquoPlease donrsquot buy our tea again."Wersquore taking some time to educate ourselves and plan proper action before we post. We stand against racism. #BlackLivesMatter.The reply from Yorkshire Tea has gained more than K likes on Twitter, and .K retweets as well.After the response from Yorkshire Tea, the vloggerchanged her Twitter profile to acknowledge the exchange, writing that she was ldquodisavowed by Yorkshire Tea.How did PG Tips get involved In response to the exchange, some Twitter users said they would be switching their tea allegiance to rival brand PG Tips -but it didnrsquot take long before thatcompany claried its own stance on the Black Lives Matter Movement.In response to Yorkshire Tea, one user named Pamela wrote in a now deleted tweet: ldquoSo now Irsquove got to buy PG Tips   Well f me. This sucks. And Yorkshire Tea is done. Good luck with the bs stance.PG Tips quickly responded with: ldquoYeah it does suck, Pamela. If you are boycotting teas that stand against racism, yoursquore going to have to find two new tea brands now. #BlackLivesMatter #Solidaritea.What is #Solidaritea The hashtag on Twitter is now full of users praising the brands for their response and enjoying cups of tea.One user wrote: ldquoAbsolutely delighted that the choice of tea in our household angers racists #BlackLivesMatterUK #SolidariteaAnother tweeted: ldquo@YorkshireTea and @PGTips yoursquove made my day #solidaritea with a screenshot of the exchange between the two brands.Another took the time to showcase what the backlash against the companies reveals about some people in the UK.They wrote: ldquoSo people are choosing to boycott tea companies such as @PGTips and @YorkshireTea because they are against racism  Absolutely pathetic. And then they say the UK isnrsquot a racist country. Yeah, okay, keep telling yourself that #solidaritea.Have other tea brands got involved with #Solidaritea Another tea brand, Tea Pigs, replied to PG Tipsrsquo and Yorkshire Tearsquos tweet with: ldquoNicely done guys. Make that three #solidaritea.There havebeen calls from users to have other brands speak out on the matter as well.ldquoWaiting for Tetley and Twinings to enter the group chathellip #solidaritea, wrote one user.Another tweeted: ldquoHas anyone heard from Twinings  Pukka  Scottish Blend  #solidaritea.ldquoWell @TwiningsUK, are you going to stand against the racists or with them  #solidaritea #BlackLivesMatter #Twinings, tweeted another user.

title: ant-dec-apologise-using-blackface-saturday-night-takeaway

title: british-gas-owner-centrica-slash-5-000-jobs-turnaround-plan
story: The boss of British Gas owner Centrica has set the company on a new path as he announced the loss of , jobs at the energy giant this year.Chris OrsquoShea said he regretted the ldquodficult decisions that had to be taken as he tried to slim down the ailing company.More than half of the job losses will come from the businessrsquos leadership roles, as Centrica revealed it would strip out three layers of middle managers, in a bid to cut bureaucracy.Mr OrsquoShea said: ldquoI truly regret that these dficult decisions will have to be made and understand the impact on the colleagues who will leave us.ldquoHowever the changes we are proposing to make are designed to arrest our decline, allow us to focus on our customers and create a sustainable company.The GMB union vowed to fight the cuts, with spokesman Justin Bowden saying: ldquoA combination of thecap and too little, too late management decisions have left a once proud brand crippled and weak.ldquoSlashing thousands more jobsisnot the answer. title: toppled-slave-trader-statue-lifted-bristol-harbour
story: The statue of slave trader Edward Colston that was pulled down during an anti-racism demonstration has been lted out of Bristol Harbour.Bristol City Council posted a video clip on Twitter of the monument being fished out of the water on Thursday morning.It tweeted: ldquoEarly this morning we retrieved the statue of Colston from Bristol Harbour.ldquoIt is being taken to a secure location before later forming part of our museums collection.Early this morning we retrieved the statue of Colston from Bristol Harbour. It is being taken to a secure location before later forming part of our museums collection. pic moRGAnNYamdash Bristol City CouncilJune , It comes after Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council said it planned to temporarily remove a statue of Scouts founder Robert Baden-Powell from Poole Quay on Thursday over concerns it may be targeted by protesters.The council said it wanted to ldquominimise the risk of any public disorder or anti-social behaviour that could arise were the statue to remain in situ while views on Lord Baden-Powell are shared.Council leader Vikki Slade said in a statement issued on Wednesday: ldquoWhilst famed for the creation of the Scouts, we also recognise that there are some aspects of Robert Baden-Powellrsquos le that are considered less worthy of commemoration.ldquoTherefore, we are removing the statue so that we can properly involve all relevant communities and groups in discussions about its future, including whether a more educational presentation of his le in a dferent setting might be more appropriate.vw,vw,px, px"A statue of Robert Baden-Powell on Poole Quay in Dorset Ms Slade said on Twitter that the decision was taken following a ldquothreat, adding: ldquoItrsquos literally less than three metres from the sea so is at huge risk.The statue was installed in  and faces Brownsea Island in Poole Harbour, where the Scout movement was started by Lord Baden-Powell.The council said it would be ldquoput into safe storage and that Dorset County Scouts ldquohave been advised and support the position.In , declassied MI files revealed that Lord Baden-Powell was invited to meet Adolf Hitler after holding friendly talks about forming closer ties with the Hitler Youth.BADEN-POWELL statue removal:A wider overdue national debate has begun about who we were, who we are  where we should go. Few historical figures comply with st C values. Simply expunging past connections from sight wonrsquot correct wrongs or help us better learn from our past. pic HHfAKSoobFmdash Tobias Ellwood MPJune , Writing on Twitter, Tobias Ellwood, Tory MP for Bournemouth East, appeared to criticise the way in which the statue removal decision was reached.He tweeted: ldquoA wider overdue national debate has begun about who we were, who we are  where we should go.ldquoFew historical figures comply with st C values. title: musicians-perform-empty-halls-live-classical-music-returns-scotland
story: Live classical music willto Scotland ndash in empty venues with no audience present.BBC Radio  will broadcast four recitals concerts from Glasgowrsquos City Halls.The solo and duo performances will feature pianists Steven Osborne and Julia Lynch, percussionist Colin Currie, bass-baritone Michael Mofidian, harpsichordist John Butt and tenor Thomas Walker.Artists are based in central Scotland to avoid unnecessary travel, the BBC said, and there will be strict compliance with social distancing guidelines.Terric news for performers and live music fans! https:t.co hWjoxYIORmdash BBC Radio May , The concerts follow the broadcast of performances from Londonrsquos empty Wigmore Hall.Alan Davey, controller of BBC Radio  and classical music, said: ldquoThere is a real primal need for live music and the refuge and respite it gives our audiences ndash the response to our Wigmore Hall series has been tremendous.ldquoWe know it also matters to musicians themselves to make this live connection again.Currie said: ldquoPlaying to an empty hall will be a new experience but I will try to channel my energies to envelop the wide community of music-lovers who are so keen and in such need of a fix of fresh music.The four Lunchtime Concerts will take place from July  to  on BBC Radio  and will be available on BBC Sounds for  days after live broadcast..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Musicians to perform in empty halls as live classical music s to Scotland

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: vision-carbon-neutral-future
story: East Lothian Council has produced a map of how it sees the new under-construction town of Blindwells and surrounding communities transform as the county tackles climate change.And the hope is that as the country comes out of the Covid- crisis, more people who have been exploring their surroundings as they worked from home or were furloughed will take part in a public consultation on its vision and embrace the concept of ldquomy space as they move forward.East Lothian Council is petitioning the Scottish Government to extend the National Development status it gave the former Cockenzie Power Station site in its National Planning Frameworkdocument to a wider area in their planned revised frameworkwhich is under reviewThe map is part of a wide-ranging consultation which will be launched on the councilrsquos consultation hub on Monday and tackles everything from the environment to travel, leisure and geothermic and renewable energy.It considers how the council can take the opportunity of creating a new town at Blindwells to look at the latest technology and reducing the town and surrounding areas carbon footprint.Among the ideas up for discussion is using groundwater from the area to create waterways and how they can be used to create geothermic energy projects.Project leader Douglas Proudfoot said the idea behind the new water features across the area was to avoid putting pipes underground to remove groundwater and utilise it instead as the new town of Blindwells develops on the former opencast coal site of the same name between Longniddry and Tranent. The firrst houses are due to be built later this year.He said: ldquoWe have a unique opportunity here with a blank canvas for a new town at a time when climate change is central to policies.ldquoI also think the Covid- pandemic has driven forward the idea that people can work from home and find alternative ways to work with the support of digital technology.Central to the vision is alternative ways to travel with an emphasis on walkways and cycle routes.A new train station at a central hub within an area the council has dubbed Greater Blindwells will provide additional access to public transport.To the north of the central hub between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry there are proposals for a water park or outdoor leisure area with the potential to create a lido, space for kayaking and other water sports.At the former Cockenzie Power Station site, less than half-a-mile away, a new centre of excellence is proposed described as a training school and ldquoexemplar development in modular manufacture and construction.The council is launching an eight-week consultation on their vision for the area from tomorrow and people will be able to go in and give their views.They are also hoping that as lockdown restrictions ease they may be able to have outdoor exhibitions for people who cannot access the proposals online and will be advertising the consultation locally so people can get in touch through the post.The Scottish Government is currently looking at revising its framework and the council has made its case for the wider area to be classed as a National Development, which will give their proposals support at a national level.The consultation will open at https:eastlothianconsultations  from Monday, June .

title: water-lovers-paradise-look-new-plans

cover the under-construction town of Blindwells and surroundingcommunities stretching from Prestonpans to Longniddry and inland to Tranent and Macmerry.East Lothian Council is petitioning the Scottish
